verses.text: Let no bishop be allowed to remove from a small city to a different one: as there is an obvious reason for this fault, accounting for such attempts; since no bishop could ever yet be found who endeavoured to be translated from a larger city to a smaller one.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:10
verses.text: It is therefore evident that such persons are inflamed with excessive covetousness and are only serving ambition in order to have the repute of possessing greater authority.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:11
verses.text: Is it then the pleasure of all that so grave an abuse be punished with great severity? For I think that men of this sort should not be admitted even to lay communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:12

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:15

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:16
verses.text: For the reason of such attempts is manifest, since in this matter no bishop has been found who would remove from a larger city to a smaller one.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:17
verses.text: It is therefore evident that these men are inflamed with excess of covetousness, and are serving ambition and aiming at the possession of power.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:18

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:41
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: But if any such person should be found so mad or audacious as to think to advance by way of excuse an affirmation that he had brought letters from the people [laity], it is plain that some few persons, corrupted by bribes and rewards, could have got up an uproar in the church, demanding, forsooth, the said man for bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:42
verses.text: I think then that practices and devices of such sort absolutely must be punished, so that a man of this kind be deemed unworthy even of lay communion in extremis.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:43
verses.text: Do ye therefore make answer whether this sentence is approved by you.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:44

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:45

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:46

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:51
verses.text: If anyone shall pass from one city to another, and shall raise up seditions, tickling the people and be assisted by them in raising a disturbance, he shall not be allowed communion even when dying.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:53
verses.text: To understand this canon aright it must be remembered that in the first ages of the Church the people were accustomed to have a share in the election of their bishop; and he whom the people demanded was usually ordained their bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:55
verses.text: This [penalty] is something unheard of and horrible, that he should not be deemed worthy of communion even at the hour of death; for it is a provision found nowhere else imposed by any canon, nor inflicted upon any sin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:56

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:57
verses.text: The Greek author Aristenus [in the above remarks] probably has not erred from the truth when he asserts that to no crime was this penalty attached, if he refers to the Eastern Churches; for Morinus himself (in the xixth chapter of the ixth book, De Penitentia), confesses that this penalty was never attached to any crime among the Easterns: nevertheless in some Churches in the first ages the three crimes of idolatry, murder, and adultery were thus punished: that is, that to those who admitted any one of these, reconciliation was denied even at his death, "and this," says Morinus, "I think no one can deny, who is at all versed in the testimony of the ancients on this point".

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:59
verses.text: The addition in the Latin text, qui sinceram fidem non habent, is found both in Dionysius Exiguus and in Isidore and the Prisca, and its meaning is as follows: "In a town, some few, especially those who have not the true faith, can be easily bribed to demand this or that person as bishop".

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:60
verses.text: The Fathers of Sardica plainly had here in view the Arians and their adherents, who, through such like machinations, when they had gained over, if only a small party in a town, sought to press into the bishoprics.

verses.text: The Synod of Antioch moreover, in 341, although the Eusebians, properly speaking, were dominant there, had laid down in the twenty-first canon a similar, only less severe, rule.

verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also it is necessary to add,โthat no bishop pass from his own province to another province in which there are bishops, unless indeed he be called by his brethren, that we seem not to close the gates of charity.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:68
verses.text: And this case likewise is to be provided for, that if in any province a bishop has some matter against his brother and fellow-bishop, neither of the two should call in as arbiters bishops from another province.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:69
verses.text: But if perchance sentence be given against a bishop in any matter and he supposes his case to be not unsound but good, in order that the question may be reopened, let us, if it seem good to your charity, honour the memory of Peter the Apostle, and let those who gave judgment write to Julius, the bishop of Rome, so that, if necessary, the case may be retried by the bishops of the neighbouring provinces and let him appoint arbiters; but if it cannot be shown that his case is of such a sort as to need a new trial, let the judgment once given not be annulled, but stand good as before.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:71
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also it is necessary to add,โthat bishops shall not pass from their own province to another province in which there are bishops, unless perchance upon invitation from their brethren, that we seem not to close the door of charity.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:72

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:104
verses.text: It is said that these Sardican decisions were simply provisional, and intended for the present necessity; because Athanasius, so hardly pressed by the Arians, could only be rescued by authorizing an appeal to the Bishop of Rome for a final judgment.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:105
verses.text: Richer, in his History of the General Councils, has elaborately defended this opinion, and Horix also has declared in its favour.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:106
verses.text: But would not all secure use of the canons of the councils be done away with if this distinction between provisional and permanent synodal decisions were admitted? Is there any sure criterion for distinguishing those canons which were only to be provisional, from the others which were made for all future centuries? The Fathers of the Synod of Sardica express themselves quite generally; is it not therefore most arbitrary on our part to insert limitations? It is beyond question that these decisions were occasioned by the very critical state of the affairs of Athanasius; but is everything only provisional that is occasioned by the circumstances of individuals? In this way the most important of the ancient canons might be set aside.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:121
verses.text: )  Bishop Gaudentius said: If it seems good to you, it is necessary to add to this decision full of sincere charity which thou hast pronounced, that if any bishop be deposed by the sentence of these neighbouring bishops, and assert that he has fresh matter in defence, a new bishop be not settled in his see, unless the bishop of Rome judge and render a decision as to this.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:123
verses.text: )  Bishop Gaudentius said: It ought to be added, if it be your pleasure, to this sentence full of sanctity which thou hast pronounced, thatโwhen any bishop has been deposed by the judgment of those bishops who have sees in neighbouring places, and he [the bishop deposed] shall announce that his case is to be examined in the city of Romeโthat no other bishop shall in any wise be ordained to his see, after the appeal of him who is apparently deposed, unless the case shall have been determined in the judgment of the Roman bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:128
verses.text: There are two distinct understandings of this canon.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:129
verses.text: The one view is that the "neighbours" of this canon are the same as the "neighbours" of the preceding canon (number iij.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:130
verses.text: ) and that the meaning of this canon therefore isโIf the court of second instance, correlating of the bishops of the neighbouring province, has pronounced the accused guilty, he still has one more appeal to a third court, viz.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:132
verses.text: This is the view taken by the Greeks, Zonaras and Balsamon, by the Ballerini, Van Espen, Palma, Walter, Natalis Alexander and many others.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:133

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:134
verses.text: The supporters of this interpretation are Peter de Marca, Tillemont, Dupin, Fleury, Remi Ceillier, Neander, Stolberg, Echhorn, Kober, and with these Hefele sides and states his reasons for doing so.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:149
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Decreed, that if any bishop is accused, and the bishops of the same region assemble and depose him from his office, and he appealing, so to speak, takes refuge with the most blessed bishop of the Roman church, and he be willing to give him a hearing, and think it right to renew the examination of his case, let him be pleased to write to those fellow-bishops who are nearest the province that they may examine the particulars with care and accuracy and give their votes on the matter in accordance with the word of truth.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:150
verses.text: And if any one require that his case be heard yet again, and at his request it seem good to move the bishop of Rome to send presbyters a latere, let it be in the power of that bishop, according as he judges it to be good and decides it to be rightโthat some be sent to be judges with the bishops and invested with his authority by whom they were sent.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:156
verses.text: But if he who asks to have his case reheard, shall by his entreaty move the Bishop of Rome to send a presbyter a latere it shall be in the power of that bishop to do what he shall resolve and determine upon; and if he shall decide that some be sent, who shall be present and be judges with the bishops invested with his authority by whom they were appointed, it shall be as he shall choose.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:157
verses.text: But if he believe that the bishops suffice to give a final decision, he shall do what he shall determine upon in his most wise judgment.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:175
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:176
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: If it happen that in a province in which there are very many bishops one bishop should stay away and by some negligence should not come to the council and assent to the appointment made by the bishops, but the people assemble and pray that the ordination of the bishop desired by them take placeโit is necessary that the bishop who stayed away should first be reminded by letters from the exarch of the province (I mean, of course, the bishop of the metropolis), that the people demand a pastor to be given them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:177
verses.text: I think that it is well to await his [the absent bishop's] arrival also.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:178
verses.text: But if after summons by letter he does not come, nor even write in reply, the wish of the people ought to be complied with.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:179
verses.text: The bishops from the neighbouring provinces also should be invited to the ordination of the bishop of the metropolis.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:180
verses.text: It is positively not permitted to ordain a bishop in a village or petty town, for which even one single presbyter is sufficient (for there is no necessity to ordain a bishop there) lest the name and authority of bishop should be made of small account, but the bishops of the province ought, as before said, to ordain bishops in those cities in which there were bishops previously; and if a city should be found with a population so large as to be thought worthy of an episcopal see, let it receive one.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:181
verses.text: Is this the pleasure of all? All answered: It is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:182
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:183
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: If it shall have happened, that in a province in which there have been very many bishops, one [i-e:, but one] bishop remains, but that he by negligence has not chosen [to ordain] a bishop, and the people have made application, the bishops of the neighbouring province ought first to address [by letter] the bishop who resides in that province, and show that the people seek a ruler [i-e:, pastor] for themselves and that this is right, so that they also may come and with him ordain a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:184
verses.text: But if he refuses to acknowledge their written communication, and leaves it unnoticed, and writes no reply, the people's request should be satisfied, so that bishops should come from the neighbouring province and ordain a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:185
verses.text: But permission is not to be given to ordain a bishop either in any village, or in an unimportant city, for which one presbyter suffices, lest the name and authority of bishop grow cheap.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:186
verses.text: Those [bishops] who are invited from another province ought not to ordain a bishop unless in the cities which have [previously] had bishops, or in a city which is so important or so populous as to be entitled to have a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:187
verses.text: Is this the pleasure of all? The synod replied: It is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:190
verses.text: If the bishops were present when the people were seeking for a bishop, and one was away, let that one be called.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:191
verses.text: But if he is willing to answer the call neither by letter nor in person, let him be ordained whom they desire.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:192
verses.text: When a Metropolitan is appointed the neighbouring bishops are to be sent for.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:193
verses.text: In a little city and town, for which one presbyter suffices, a bishop is not to be appointed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:226

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:227
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Our importunity and great pertinacity and unjust petitions have brought it about that we do not have as much favour and confidence as we ought to enjoy.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:228
verses.text: For many of the bishops do not intermit resorting to the imperial Court, especially the Africans, who, as we have learned from our beloved brother and fellow-bishop, Gratus, do not accept salutary counsels, but so despise them that one man carries to the Court petitions many and diverse and of no possible benefit to the Church, and does not (as ought to be done and as is fitting) assist and help the poor and the laity or the widows, but is intriguing to obtain worldly dignities and offices for certain persons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:229
verses.text: This evil then causes enfeeblement [better, murmuring (read ฯฮฟฮฝฮธฯฯฯฮผแฝนฮฝ or ฯฮฟฮฝฮธฮฟฯฯฯฮผแฝนฮฝ)], not without some scandal and blame to us.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:230
verses.text: But I account it quite proper for a bishop to give assistance to one oppressed by some one, or to a widow suffering injustice, or, again, an orphan robbed of his estate, always provided that these persons have a just cause of petition.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:231
verses.text: If, then, beloved brethren, this seems good to all, do ye decree that no bishop shall go to the imperial Court except those whom our most pious emperor may summon by his own letters.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:232
verses.text: Yet since it often happens that persons condemned for their offences to deportation or banishment to an island, or who have received some sentence or other, beg for mercy and seek refuge with the Church [i-e:, take sanctuary], such persons are not to be refused assistance, but pardon should be asked for them without delay and without hesitation.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:233
verses.text: If this, then, is also your pleasure, do ye all vote assent.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:234
verses.text: All gave answer: Be this also decreed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:235
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:236
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Importunities and excessive pertinacity and unjust petitions have caused us to have too little favour or confidence, while certain bishops cease not to go to the Court, especially the Africans, who (as we have learned) spurn and contemn the salutary counsels of our most holy brother and fellow-bishop, Gratus, so that they not only bring to the Court many and diverse petitions (not for the good of the Church nor, as is usual and right, to succour the poor or widows or orphans), but even seek to obtain worldly dignities and offices for certain persons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:237
verses.text: This evil therefore stirs up at times not only murmurings, but even scandals.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:238
verses.text: But it is proper that bishops should intercede for persons suffering from violence and oppression, afflicted widows and defrauded orphans, provided, nevertheless, that these persons have a just cause or petition.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:239
verses.text: If, then, brethren dearly beloved, such be your pleasure, do we decree that no bishops go to the Court except those who may have been invited or summoned by letters of the God-fearing emperor.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:240
verses.text: But since it often happens that those who are suffering from injustice or who are condemned for their offences to deportation or banishment to an island, or, in short, have received some sentence or other, seek refuge with the mercy of the Church, such persons should be succoured and pardon be begged for them without hesitation.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:241
verses.text: Decree this, therefore, if it be your pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:242
verses.text: All said: It is our pleasure and be it decreed.

verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:245
verses.text: When an orphan, widow, and other desolate persons are oppressed by force let the bishop give them succour and approach the Emperor; but through a pretext of this kind let him not be a hanger on of the camp, but rather let him send a deacon.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:247
verses.text: The "salutary counsels" (salutaria consilia) here seem to be synodical admonitions, as Zonaras notes; and these might well be ascribed to Gratus, the bishop of Carthage, because many of the African synods were held under his presidency and direction.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:267
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also let your sagacity determine, thatโinasmuch as this was decreed in order that a bishop might not fall under censure by going to the Courtโthat if any have such petitions as we mentioned above, they should send these by one of their deacons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:268
verses.text: For the person of a subordinate does not excite jealousy, and what shall be granted [by the Emperor] can thus be reported more quickly.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:269
verses.text: All answered: Be this also decreed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:270
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:271
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also your forethought should provide forโinasmuch as ye have made this decree in order that the audacity of bishops might not labour [or, be observed] to go to Court.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:272
verses.text: Whosoever therefore shall have or receive petitions such as we have mentioned above, let them send these [each] by a deacon of his, because the person of a minister is not an object of jealousy, and he will be able to report more quickly what he has obtained.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:277
verses.text: This decree is threefold.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:278
verses.text: First, that the bishop in going to Court should not fall under suspicion either at Court or of his own people that he was approaching the Prince to obtain some cause of his own.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:279
verses.text: Second, according to the interpretation of Zonaras, "that no one should be angry with the Minister or Deacon who tarried in camp, as the bishop had departed thence".

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:280
verses.text: And third, that the Minister could carry away what he had asked for, that is (according to Zonaras), the letters of the Emperor pardoning the fault, or such like other matters.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:281
verses.text: Canon IX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:282
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:283
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also, I think, follows, that, if in any province whatever, bishops send petitions to one of their brothers and fellow-bishops, he that is in the largest city, that is, the metropolis, should himself send his deacon and the petitions, providing him also with letters commendatory, writing also of course in succession to our brethren and fellow-bishops, if any of them should be staying at that time in the places or cities in which the most pious Emperor is administering public affairs.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:284
verses.text: But if any of the bishops should have friends at the Court and should wish to make requests of them as to some proper object, let him not be forbidden to make such requests through his deacon and move these [friends] to give their kind assistance as his desire.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:285
verses.text: But those who come to Rome ought, as I said before, to deliver to our beloved brother and fellow-bishop, Julius, the petitions which they have to give, in order that he may first examine them, lest some of them should be improper, and so, giving them his own advocacy and care, shall send them to the Court.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:286
verses.text: All the Bishops made answer that such was their pleasure and that the regulation was most proper.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:287
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:288
verses.text: )  This also seems to follow, that from whatever province bishops shall send petitions to that brother and fellow-bishop of ours who has his see in the metropolis, he [the metropolitan] should dispatch his deacon with the petitions, providing him with commendatory letters of like tenour to our brethren and fellow-bishops at that time resident in those regions and cities in which the fortunate and blessed Emperor is ruling the State.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:289
verses.text: If however a bishop who seeks to obtain some petition (a worthy one, that is) has friends in the palace, he is not forbidden to make his request through his deacon and to advise those who, he knows, can kindly intercede for him in his absence.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:290

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:291
verses.text: But let those who come to Rome, deliver, as before said, to our most holy brother and fellow-bishop, the bishop of the Roman church, the petitions which they bear, that he also may examine whether they are worthy and just, and let him give diligence and care that they be forwarded to the Court.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:292
verses.text: All said that such was their pleasure and that the regulation was proper.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:293
verses.text: Bishop Alypius said: If they have incurred the discomforts of travel for the sake of orphans and widows or any in distress and having cases that are not unjust, they will have some good reason [for their journey]; but now since they chiefly make requests which cannot be granted without envy and reproach, it is not necessary for them to go to Court.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:296
verses.text: If one brother sends to another, let the Metropolitan fortify the nuncio with letters; and let him write to the bishops, who have the matter in hand, to protect the nuncio.

verses.text: Here the Latin is not only a translation but an interpretation of the Greek text, for it distinctly says that every bishop shall send the petition he intends to present at court first to his Metropolitan, who shall send it in.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:319
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also I think necessary.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:320
verses.text: Ye should consider with all thoroughness and care, that if some rich man or professional advocate be desired for bishop, he be not ordained until he have fulfilled the ministry of reader, deacon, and presbyter, in order that, passing by promotion through the several grades, he may advance (if, that is, he be found worthy) to the height of the episcopate.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:321
verses.text: And he shall remain in each order assuredly for no brief time, that so his faith, his reputable life, his steadfastness of character and considerateness of demeanour may be well-known, and that he, being deemed worthy of the divine sacerdotal office [sacerdotium, i-e:, the episcopate] may enjoy the highest honour.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:322
verses.text: For it is not fitting, nor does discipline or good conversation allow to proceed to this act rashly or lightly, so as to ordain a bishop or presbyter or deacon hastily; as thus he would rightly be accounted a novice, especially since also the most blessed Apostle, he who was the teacher of the Gentiles, is seen to have forbidden hasty ordinations; for the test of [even] the longest period will not unreasonably be required to exemplify the conversation and character of each [candidate].

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:323
verses.text: All said that this was their pleasure and that it must be absolutely irreversible.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:324
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:325
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also I think it necessary for you to consider most carefully, that if perchance some rich man or professional advocate or ex-official be desired for bishop, he be not ordained until he have fulfilled the ministry of a reader and the office of deacon and presbyter, and so ascend, if he have shown himself worthy, through the several grades to the height of the episcopate.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:326
verses.text: For by these promotions which in any case take a considerable length of time can be tested his faith, his discretion, his gravity and modesty.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:327
verses.text: And if he be found worthy, let him be honoured with the divine sacerdotal office [i-e: the episcopate].

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:328
verses.text: For it is not fitting, nor does order or discipline allow, that one be rashly or lightly ordained bishop, presbyter or deacon, who is a novice, especially since also the blessed Apostle, the teacher of the Gentiles, is seen to have expressly forbidden it.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:329
verses.text: But those [should be ordained] whose life has been tested and their merit approved by length of time.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:330

verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon X.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:333
verses.text: No lawyer, teacher, or gentleman (ฯฮปฮฟแฝปฯฮนฮฟฯ) shall be made a bishop without passing through the holy orders.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:334
verses.text: Nor shall the space of time between the orders be made too brief, that there may be a better proof of his faith and good conversation.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:335
verses.text: For otherwise he is a neophyte.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:336
verses.text: This is Canon XIII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:337
verses.text: of Dionysius, Isidore, and the Prisca.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:338
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:339
verses.text: By Scholasticus de foro ["professional advocate"] must be understood an eloquent pleader of difficult causes, who being bound up in forensic disputes and strifes, may be presumed to be little fitted for the priesthood, and therefore to need a more strict examination.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:340
verses.text: The Synodal approbation is lacking in Dionysius as given by Justellus, as well as in that of the Roman Code, but is found in Labbe's reprint of Dionysius and Isidore.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:341
verses.text: This Canon is found in the Corpus Juris Canonici, Gratian's Decretum, P.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:342
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:343
verses.text: , Dist.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:344
verses.text: lxj.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:346
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:347
verses.text: Canon XI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:348
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:349
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also we ought to decree, that when a bishop comes from one city to another city, or from one province to another province, to indulge boastfulness, ministering to his own praises rather than serving religious devotion, and wishes to prolong his stay [in a city], and the bishop of that city is not skilled in teaching, let him [the visiting bishop] not do despite to the bishop of the place and attempt by frequent discourses to disparage him and lessen his repute (for this device is wont to cause tumults), and strive by such arts to solicit and wrest to himself another's throne, not scrupling to abandon the church committed to him and to procure translation to another.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:350
verses.text: A definite limit of time should therefore be set in such a case, especially since not to receive a bishop is accounted the part of rude and discourteous persons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:351
verses.text: Ye remember that in former times our fathers decreed that if a layman were staying in a city and should not come to divine worship for three [successive] Sundays [that is], for three [full] weeks, he should be repelled from communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:352
verses.text: If then this has been decreed in the case of laymen, it is neither needful, nor fitting, nor yet even expedient that a bishop, unless he has some grave necessity or difficult business, should be very long absent from his own church and distress the people committed to him.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:353
verses.text: All the bishops said: We decide that this decree also is most proper.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:354
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:355
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also ye ought to determine.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:356
verses.text: If a bishop comes from one city to another city, or from his own province to another province, and serving ambition rather than devotion, wishes to remain resident for a long time in a strange city, and then (as it perchance happens that the bishop of the place is not so practised or so learned as himself) he, the stranger, should begin to do him despite and deliver frequent discourses to disparage him and lessen his repute, not hesitating by this device to leave the church assigned him and remove to that which is another'sโdo ye then [in such a case] set a limit of time [for his stay in the city], because on the one hand to refuse to receive a bishop is discourteous, and on the other his too long stay is mischievous.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:357
verses.text: Provision must be made against this.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:358
verses.text: I remember that in a former council our brethren decreed that if any layman did not attend divine service in a city in which he was staying three Sundays, that is, for three weeks, he should be deprived of communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:359
verses.text: If then this has been decreed in the case of laymen, it is far less lawful and fitting that a bishop, if there be no grave necessity detaining him, should be absent from his church longer than the time above written.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:360
verses.text: All said that such was their pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:361
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:362
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:363
verses.text: A bishop when called in by another bishop, if he that called him is unskilled, must not be too assiduous in preaching, for this would be indecorous to the unlearned bishop, and an attack upon his bishopric.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:364
verses.text: And both improper.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:365
verses.text: Without grave necessity it is undesirable for a bishop to be absent from his church.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:366
verses.text: This is Canon XIV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:367
verses.text: of the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:368
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:369
verses.text: To understand this canon it must be again remembered that in the first ages of the Church bishops were wont to be appointed at the demand of the people; wherefore whoever were going around after the episcopate, were accustomed to solicit the hearts of the people, and to make it their study to win their affections.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:370
verses.text: Canon XII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:371
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:372
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Since no case should be left unprovided for, let this also be decreed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:373
verses.text: Some of our brethren and fellow-bishops are known to possess very little private property in the cities in which they are placed as bishops, but have great possessions in other places, with which they are, moreover, able to help the poor.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:374
verses.text: I think then permission should be given them, if they are to visit their estates and attend to the gathering of the harvest, to pass three Sundays, that is, to stay for three weeks, on their estates, and to assist at divine worship and celebrate the liturgy in the nearest church in which a presbyter holds service, in order that they may not be seen to be absent from worship, and in order that they may not come too frequently to the city in which there is a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:375
verses.text: In this way their private affairs will suffer no loss from their absence and they will be seen to be clear from the charge of ambition and arrogance.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:376
verses.text: All the bishops said: This decree also is approved by us.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:377
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:378
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Since no case should be left unprovided for [let this also be decreed].

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:379
verses.text: There are some of our brother-bishops, who do not reside in the city in which they are appointed bishops, either because they have but little property there, while they are known to have considerable estates elsewhere, or, it may be, through affection for kith and kin and in complaisance to these.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:380
verses.text: Let this much be permitted them, to go to their estates to superintend and dispose of their harvest, and [for this purpose] to remain over three Sundays, that is, for three weeks, if it be necessary, on their estates; or else, if there is a neighbouring city in which there is a presbyter, in order that they may not be seen to pass Sunday without church, let them go thither, so that [in this way] neither will their private affairs suffer loss from their absence, nor will they, by frequent going to the city in which a bishop is resident, incur the suspicion of ambition and place-seeking.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:381
verses.text: All said that this was approved by them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:382
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:383
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:384
verses.text: If a bishop has possessions outside his diocese, and visits them, let him be careful not to remain there more than three Lord's days.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:385
verses.text: For thus his own flock will be enriched by him, and he himself will avoid the charge of arrogance.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:386
verses.text: This is Canon XV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:387
verses.text: of the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:388
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:389
verses.text: As Balsamon notes, this canon is an appendix to that which goes before, and the context of the canon indicates this clearly enough; for while the last canon decrees that no bishop is to be absent from his diocese for more than three Lord's days, without grave necessity, in this canon a certain modification is introduced with regard to certain bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:390
verses.text: Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:391
verses.text: According to the Latin text of Dionysius, it is: "Some bishops do not reside in their Cathedral town, etc".

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:392
verses.text: Isidore and the Prisca, however, are nearer the Greek text, as instead of resident they more rightly read possident.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:393
verses.text: Canon XIII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:394
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:395
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Be this also the pleasure of all.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:396
verses.text: If any deacon or presbyter or any of the clergy be excommunicated and take refuge with another bishop who knows him and who is aware that he has been removed from communion by his own bishop, [that other bishop] must not offend against his brother bishop by admitting him to communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:397
verses.text: And if any dare to do this, let him know that he must present himself before an assembly of bishops and give account.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:398
verses.text: All the bishops said: This decision will assure peace at all times and preserve the concord of all.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:399
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:400
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: Be this also the pleasure of all.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:401
verses.text: If a deacon or presbyter or any of the clergy be refused communion by his own bishop and go to another bishop, and he with whom he has taken refuge shall know that he has been repelled by his own bishop, then must he not grant him communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:402
verses.text: But if he shall do so, let him know that he must give account before an assembly of bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:403
verses.text: All said: This decision will preserve peace and maintain concord.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:404
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:405
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XIII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:406
verses.text: Whoso knowingly admits to communion one excommunicated by his own bishop is not without blame.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:407
verses.text: This is Canon XVI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:408
verses.text: of the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:409
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:410
verses.text: The present canon agrees with Canon V.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:411
verses.text: of Nice and with Canon IV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:412
verses.text: of Antioch, on which canons see the notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:413
verses.text: The Synod's approbation of this canon is found in Dionysius, Isidore, and in the Roman Codex apud Hervetus; but it is lacking from Balsamon and Zonaras.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:414
verses.text: Canon XIV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:415
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:416
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: I must not fail to speak of a matter which constantly urgeth me.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:417
verses.text: If a bishop be found quick to anger (which ought not to sway such a man), and he, suddenly moved against a presbyter or deacon, be minded to cast him out of the Church, provision must be made that such a one be not condemned too hastily [or read แผฮธแฟถฮฟฮฝ, if innocent] and deprived of communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:418
verses.text: All said: Let him that is cast out be authorized to take refuge with the bishop of the metropolis of the same province.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:419
verses.text: And if the bishop of the metropolis is absent, let him hasten to the bishop that is nearest, and ask to have his case carefully examined.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:420
verses.text: For a hearing ought not to be denied those who ask it.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:421
verses.text: And that bishop who cast out such a one, justly or unjustly, ought not to take it ill that examination of the case be made, and his decision confirmed or revised.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:422
verses.text: But, until all the particulars have been examined with care and fidelity, he who is excluded from communion ought not to demand communion in advance of the decision of his case.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:423
verses.text: And if any of the clergy who have met [to hear the case] clearly discern arrogance and pretentiousness in him, inasmuch as it is not fitting to suffer insolence or unjust censure, they ought to correct such an one with somewhat harsh and grievous language, that men may submit to and obey commands that are proper and right.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:424
verses.text: For as the bishop ought to manifest sincere love and regard to his subordinates, so those who are subject to him ought in like manner to perform the duties of their ministry in sincerity towards their bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:425
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:426
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: I must not fail to speak of a matter which further moveth me.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:427
verses.text: If some bishop is perchance quick to anger (which ought not to be the case) and, moved hastily and violently against one of his presbyters or deacons, be minded to cast him out of the Church, provision must be made that an innocent man be not condemned or deprived of communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:428
verses.text: Therefore let him that is cast out be authorized to appeal to the neighbouring bishops and let his case be heard and examined into more diligently.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:429
verses.text: For a hearing ought not to be denied one who asks it.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:430
verses.text: And let that bishop who cast him out, justly or unjustly, take it patiently that the matter is discussed, so that his sentence may either be approved by a number [of judges] or else revised.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:431
verses.text: Nevertheless, until all the particulars shall be examined with care and fidelity, no one else ought to presume to admit to communion him who was excluded therefrom in advance of the decision of his case.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:432
verses.text: If, however, those who meet to hear it observe arrogance and pride in [such] clergy, inasmuch as it surely is not fitting for a bishop to suffer wrong or insult, let them correct them with some severity of language, that they may obey a bishop whose commands are proper and right.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:433
verses.text: For as he [the bishop] ought to manifest sincere love and charity to his clergy, so his ministers ought for their part to render unfeigned obedience to their bishop.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:434
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:435
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XIV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:436
verses.text: One condemned out of anger, if he asks for assistance, should be heard.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:437
verses.text: But until [he shall have asked for] the assistance let him remain excommunicated.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:438
verses.text: This is Canon XVII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:439
verses.text: of the Latin version.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:440
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:441
verses.text: This canon is intended especially to aid presbyters, deacons, and other clerics, who have been excommunicated precipitately and without just cause, or suspended by their own bishop in his anger and fury.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:442
verses.text: โฆThe canon, moreover, admonishes that the bishop with regard to whose sentence the dispute has arisen shall patiently consent to the discussion of the matter de novo, whether his decision be sustained by the majority or emended.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:443
verses.text: And let bishops and other prelates who have spiritual jurisdiction over the clergy note this, who cannot bear with equanimity that a word should be said against their decisions, but exact a kind of blind obedience, even frequently with great conscientious suffering to their very best ecclesiastics; and in such cases as do not promptly and blindly obey them, the clergy are traduced as rebels and even a patient hearing is refused to them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:444
verses.text: This canon is found in the Corpus Juris Canonici, Gratian's Decretum, P.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:445
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:446
verses.text: , Causa XI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:448
verses.text: iij.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:450
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:451
verses.text: [After Canon XIV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:452
verses.text: ]  Canon XVIII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:453
verses.text: (Of the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:454
verses.text: )  Bishop Januarius said: Let your holiness also decree this, that no bishop be allowed to try to gain for himself a minister in the church of a bishop of another city and ordain him to one of his own parishes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:455
verses.text: All said: Such is our pleasure, inasmuch as discord is apt to spring from contentions in this matter, and therefore the sentence of us all forbids anyone to presume to do  Note.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:456
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:457
verses.text: It is manifest that these two canons [xviii.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:458
verses.text: of the Latin and xv.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:459
verses.text: of the Greek], contain the resolution of the same case, and therefore it is that the Greeks keep only the former which contains the decree of the synod, made on Hosius's motion, the suggestion having been made by Januarius the bishop: which suggestion makes the first of these canons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:460
verses.text: [i-e: Latin canon xviij.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:461
verses.text: ]      Canon XV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:462
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:463
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: And let us all decree this also, that if any bishop should ordain to any order the minister of another from another diocese without the consent of his own bishop, such an ordination should be accounted invalid and not confirmed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:464
verses.text: And if any take upon themselves to do this they ought to be admonished and corrected by our brethren and fellow-bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:465
verses.text: All said: Let this decree also stand unalterable.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:466
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:467
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This also we all decree, that if any [bishop] should ordain the minister of another from another diocese without the consent and will of his own bishop, his ordination be not ratified.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:468
verses.text: And whoever shall have taken upon himself to do this ought to be admonished and corrected by our brethren and fellow-bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:469
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:470
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XV.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:471
verses.text: If one places a foreign minister without the knowledge of his own bishop in any grade (แผฮผฮฒฮฑฮธฮผฮฟฮฝ, in aliquo gradu), he has indeed made the appointment, but it is without force.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:472
verses.text: This is Canon XIX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:473
verses.text: in the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:474
verses.text: Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:475
verses.text: Fuchs, in his Bibliothek der Kirchenversammlungen (Pt.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:476
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:478
verses.text: 123, note 125), thinks he has discovered a difference between this canon and the exclusively Latin one preceding it, in that the latter supposes the case of a bishop ordaining a foreign cleric, over whom he has no jurisdiction, to a higher grade, with the view of retaining him for his own diocese; while the otherโfifteenth or nineteenth canonโtreats of a case where such an ordination takes place without the ordaining bishop intending to keep the person ordained for his own diocese.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:479
verses.text: Van Espen is of another opinion, and maintains that both canons obviously refer to one and the same case, for which reason the Greek text has only inserted one of them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:480
verses.text: It is certain that the text of both canons, as we have it, does not clearly indicate the difference conjectured by Fuchs, but that it may easily be found there.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:481
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:482
verses.text: If the reading of all the Latins and Greeks is decisive, this canon only treats of the ordination of those already ministers or clerics, and so the Greek commentators Balsamon, Zonaras, and Aristenus understood it, as is evident from their annotations.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:483
verses.text: But Gratus, Bishop of Carthage, and Primate of Africa, in the First Synod of Carthage testified that in this canon it was decreed, that without the licence of his own bishop, a layman of another diocese was not to be ordained, and this interpretation or rather extension of the Canon, was received everywhere, as is demonstrated by the fifty-sixth of the African Code.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:484
verses.text: This together with Canon XIX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:485
verses.text: of the Latin text are found as one in the Corpus Juris Canonici (Gratian's Decretum, P.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:486
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:487
verses.text: , Dist.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:488
verses.text: lxxj.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:490
verses.text: j.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:491
verses.text: Canon XVI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:492
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:493
verses.text: )  Bishop Aรซtius said: Ye are not ignorant how important and how large is the metropolitan city of Thessalonica.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:494
verses.text: Accordingly presbyters and deacons often come to it from other provinces and, not content with staying a short time, remain and make it their permanent place of residence, or are compelled with difficulty and after a very long delay to return to their own churches.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:495
verses.text: A decree should be made bearing on this matter.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:496
verses.text: Bishop Hosius said: Let those decrees which have been made in the case of bishops, be observed as to these persons also.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:497
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:498
verses.text: )  Bishop Aรซtius said: Ye are not ignorant how large and important is the city of Thessalonica.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:499
verses.text: Presbyters and deacons often come to it from other regions, and are not content to remain a short time, but either make their residence there or at least are with difficulty compelled to return after a long interval to their own place.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:500
verses.text: All said: Those limits of time which have been decreed in the case of bishops ought to be observed as to these persons also.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:501
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:502
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XVI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:503
verses.text: What things have been decreed for bishops with regard to the length of their absence, applies also to presbyters and deacons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:504
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:505
verses.text: This canon needs no explanation.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:506
verses.text: Canon XVII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:507
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:508
verses.text: )  At the suggestion moreover of our brother Olympius, we are pleased to decree this also: That if a bishop suffer violence and is unjustly cast out either on account of his discipline or for his confession of [the faith of] the Catholic Church or for his defence of the truth, and, fleeing from danger, although innocent and devout [or, innocent and being under charge of high treason], comes to another city, let him not be forbidden to stay there until he is restored or until deliverance can be found from the violence and injustice that have been done him.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 1:509
verses.text: For it would be harsh indeed and most oppressive that one who has suffered unjust expulsion should not be harboured by us; as such a man ought to be received with the greatest consideration and cordiality.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:1
verses.text: All said: This also is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:2
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:3
verses.text: )  At the suggestion of our brother Olympius, we are pleased to decree this also: That if any suffer violence and is unjustly cast out on account of his discipline and his Catholic confession or for his defence of the truth, and, fleeing from dangers, although innocent and devout, comes to another city, let him not be forbidden to stay there until he can return or his wrong has been redressed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:4
verses.text: For it is harsh and unfeeling that he who is suffering persecution should not be received; indeed, great cordiality and abundant consideration should be shown him.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:5
verses.text: All the synod said: All that has been decreed the Catholic Church spread abroad throughout all the world will preserve and maintain.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:6
verses.text: And all the bishops of the various provinces who had assembled subscribed thus:  I, N.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:7
verses.text: , bishop of the city of N.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:8
verses.text: and the province of N.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:9
verses.text: , so believe as above is written.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:10
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:11
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XVII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:12
verses.text: If a bishop goes into another province after he has been unjustly expelled from his own, he should be received, until he has been delivered from his injury.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:13
verses.text: This is Canon XXI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:23
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:24
verses.text: )  Bishop Gaudentius said: Thou knowest, brother Aรซtius, that since thou wast made bishop, peace hath continued to rule [in thy diocese].

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:25
verses.text: In order that no remnants of discord concerning ecclesiastics remain, it seems good that those who were ordained by Musaeus and by Eutychianus, provided no fault be found in them, should all be received.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:26
verses.text: (This canon is wanting in the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:27
verses.text: )      Canon XIX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:28
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:29
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: This is the sentence of my mediocrity [i-e:, unworthiness]โthat, since we ought to be gentle and patient and to be constant in compassion towards all, those who were once advanced to clerical office in the Church by certain of our brethren, if they are not willing to return to the churches to which they were nominated [or, espoused], should for the future not be received, and that neither Eutychianus should continue to vindicate to himself the name of bishop, nor yet that Musaeus be accounted a bishop; but that if they should seek for lay communion, it should not be denied them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:30
verses.text: All said: Such is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:31
verses.text: (This canon is wanting in the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:32
verses.text: )  Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:34
verses.text: and XIX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:35
verses.text: A clergyman who does not live in the Church among whose clergy he is enrolled should not be received.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:36
verses.text: Eutychian and Musaeus shall not have the name of bishops.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:37
verses.text: But let them be admitted to communion with the laity, if they wish.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:38
verses.text: Both of these canons are lacking in the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:39

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:40
verses.text: It is clear that the reason why these two canons do not exist in the Latin text is that they did not apply to the Latin Church and only contained a special rule for Thessalonica.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:41
verses.text: Canon XX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:42
verses.text: (Greek.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:43
verses.text: )  Bishop Gaudentius said: These things wholesomely, duly, and fitly decreed, in the estimation of us the bishops [ฯแฟถฮฝ แผฑฮตฯแฝณฯฮฝ] such as are pleasing both to God and to man will not be able to obtain due force and validity, unless fear [of a penalty] be added to the decrees proclaimed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:44
verses.text: For we ourselves know that through the shamelessness of a few, the divine and right reverend title of bishop [of the ฯแฟฯ แผฑฮตฯฯฯแฝปฮฝฮทฯ] hath often come into condemnation.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:45
verses.text: If therefore any one, moved by arrogance and ambition rather than seeking to please God, should have the hardihood to pursue a different course of action, contrary to the decree of all, let him know beforehand that he must give account and defend himself on this charge, and lose the honour and dignity of the episcopate.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:46
verses.text: All answered: This sentence is proper and right, and such is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:47
verses.text: And this decree will be most widely known and best carried into effect, if each of those bishops among us who have sees on the thoroughfares or highway, on seeing a bishop [pass by] shall inquire into the cause of his passage and his place of destination.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:48
verses.text: And if at his departure he shall find that he is going to the Court, he will direct his inquiries with reference to the objects [of a resort to the Court] above mentioned.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:49
verses.text: And if he come by invitation let no obstacle be put in the way of his departure.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:50
verses.text: But if he is trying to go to the Court out of ostentation, as hath afore been said by your charity, or to urge the petitions of certain persons, let neither his letters be signed nor let such an one be received to communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:51
verses.text: All said: Be this also decreed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:52
verses.text: (Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:53
verses.text: )  Bishop Gaudentius said: These things which you have wholesomely and suitably provided [in your decrees] pleasing in [or, to] the estimation of all both [or, and] to God and to men, can obtain force and validity only in case fear [of a penalty] be added to this your action.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:54
verses.text: For we ourselves know that through the shamelessness of a few the sacred and venerable sacerdotal [โepiscopal] name hath been many times and oft brought to blame.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:55
verses.text: If therefore anyone attempts to oppose the judgment of all and seeks to serve ambition rather than please God, he must be given to know that he will have to render an account and lose office and rank.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:56
verses.text: This can be carried into effect only provided each of us whose see is on the highway shall, if he sees a bishop pass, inquire into the cause of his journey, ascertain his destination, and if he finds that he is on his way to the Court, satisfy himself as to what is contained above [i-e:, as to his objects at Court], lest perhaps he has come by invitation, that permission may be given him to proceed.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:57
verses.text: If, however, as your holiness mentioned above, he is going to Court to urge petitions and applications for office, let neither his letters be signed nor let him be received to communion.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:58
verses.text: All said that this was proper and right and that this regulation was approved by them.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:59
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:60
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:63
verses.text: ]  If any bishop tries out of pride to do away with what has been decreed admirably, and in a manner pleasing to God, he shall lose his episcopate.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:64
verses.text: A bishop who shall see a bishop on his way to the camp, if he shall know that he goes there for any of the before-mentioned causes, let him not trouble him, but if otherwise let him pronounce excommunication against him.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:65
verses.text: This is Canon XI.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:66
verses.text: of the Latin.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:67
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:68
verses.text: After the words ["honour and dignity"] according to Balsamon and Zonaras, as also Gentian Hervetus, there follows the approbation of the synod in these words: "All answered, This opinion is becoming and well-pleasing to us," which indicate this to be the end of the canon; and therefore the Greeks make of this two distinct canons.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:69
verses.text: Dionysius and Isidore make but one canon,โฆand this appears to be more congruous on account of the subject-matter of the first part, and will be manifest by connecting the two parts together.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:70
verses.text: Van Espen follows Zonaras and Balsamon in understanding "Bishops in Canali," as such as were set on the public roads and public highways, or rather "in cities which are on the public highways, or 'Canals,' by which they that pass go without labour, as in a canal or aqueduct the water flows, for aqueduct and canal are the same thing in the Roman tongue".

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:71
verses.text: [After Canon XX.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:72
verses.text: ]  Canon XII.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:73
verses.text: (Of the Latin Texts.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:74
verses.text: )  Bishop Hosius said: But some discretion is here requisite, brethren dearly beloved, in case some should come to those cities which are on the highway still ignorant of what has been decreed in the council.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:75
verses.text: The bishop of such a city ought therefore to admonish him [a bishop so arriving], and instruct him to send his deacon from that place.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:76
verses.text: Upon this admonition he must, however, himself return to his diocese.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:77
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:78
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:79
verses.text: This proposition of Hosius in the Roman Codex is joined as an appendix to the preceding canon.

verses.name: Council of Sardica 2:80
verses.text: The Greeks omit it altogether, very likely either because it seemed to be a proposition of Hosius's rather than a synodal canon, for no adoption by the synod is recorded: or else because, even if it were a decree, it was only of temporary character, that is to say, until the canons had been sufficiently promulgated, and therefore some on the ground of ignorance might be exempt from the threatened penalties.
